Hopkins debaters triumphantly returned with seven awards from tournaments held at Columbia, Yeshiva, and
Rutgers universities last weekend. Toby
Simon, Debate Council vice-president,
termed the successes as "extremely exoeptional," noting also that it was the
first time that four two-man teams had
been sent out at one time.
Of the 85 teams representing 60
schools at the Columbia tournament,
the Hopkins team of Jon Alpert and
George Miller took first place, emerging
undefeated in the switchside competition. David Thompson and Richard Banjevic placed third, while Alpert, who is
president of the Debate Council, received
the second place individual speaker

Simon observed that the council this
year has sustained the momentum initiated last year with a first-place vie-.
tory at New York University. He attributed the council's current success to
Increased intramural debating, the new
blood of the past two freshman classes,
and a strong win philosophy also generated over the past two years.

award.
Yeshiva Tourney
The same team participated on Sunday in the Yeshiva tournament, where
they finished first among 25 teams in
both affirmative and negative categories,
the first time in ten years at Yeshiva
that such a feat had been accomplished.
Since two Hopkins teams were scheduled to meet in the final round, the
affirmative team deferred to the second
place team Iona, which was then
beaten by Alpert and Miller, confirming
Hopkins' first place standing.
In addition, Alpert placed first and
Miller second as individual negative
speakers, with Thompson gaining second place among affirmative debaters.
Meanwhile, at the Rutgers tournament, the negative team of Terry Leveck
and James Jacobs took second place in
overall standings. Jacobs also won second place in the original oratory competition.

JHU Bookstore
Supports School
By JIM WULACH
The university earns about $25,000
from bookstore profits every year, according to a report recently written by
Dr. Charles Hunt, of the Hopkins
Geography Department. Whereas many
college bookstores are non-profit organizations with education as their primary
purpose, the dominant philosophy of
the University Bookstore is that it is
"first and last a business enterprise."
A survey conducted five years ago and
signed by 85 faculty members, including
19 departmen chairmen, recommended
that improvements be made. The survey
indicated that "the Hopkins bookstore
Is one of the poorer ones among major
Universities, for it has not been allowed
the staff, space, and facilities to develop
otherwise." However, present plans for
change, which include more bookstore
space, and a rearrangement of books
according to subject, are "only palliative
and quite inadequate," Dr. Hunt stated.
(Continued on Page 3)

Tuesday evening marked the commencement of the annual rush period at
Hopkins, as fraternity men converged
on the freshman dormitories en masse.
Both fraternities and freshmen are expected to exercise great selectivity, the
freshmen looking for the most congenial
fraternity and each fraternity seeking a
qualitatively and quantitatively superior
pledge class.
Tonight begins the two-week round of
open-house parties, with the freshmen
being welcomed at those fraternities
south of the campus from 8 p.m. until
1 a.m. These houses are Alpha Delta Phi,
Alpha Tau Omega, Alpha Epsilon Pi,
Sigma Phi Epsilon, Phi Epsilon Pi, Zeta
Beta Tau, and Kappa Alpha. Saturday
evening the freshmen are all invited to
visit Delta Phi, Delta Upsilon, Phi Gamma Delta, Tau Epsilon Phi, Phi Sigma
Delta, and Beta Theta Pi.
Next week will follow the same schedule of rush Tuesday evening from seven
to ten p.m. and Wednesday and Thursday afternoon rush from noon to five
p.m. However,, those fraternities which
hold parties tonight will have their second parties on Saturday of next week,
and those fraternities which will have
their parties tomorrow evening will
have their second parties next Friday.
For the third and final week of rush,
all fraternities will have invitational
parties on Friday evening, March 4, followed by their private pledge parties
on Pledge Saturday, March 5, after the
freshmen have submitted their bids
( with a five-dollar fee) to the IFC that
morning.
(Continued on Page 6)

Hopkins Honors Comsat Head
Mr. James McCormack, chairman of
the board of the Communications Satellite Corporation and former Vice
President of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, will deliver the
principal address at the Hopkins Commemoration Day ceremonies, Tuesday
February 22. 3 p.m. in Shriver
President Eisenhower will preside at
the ceremonies marking the 90th anniversary of the founding of the University. Classes are cancelled for the

up a global commercial communications system through the use of orbiting satellites, Comsat played a leading
role in the launching of Early Bird on
April 6, 1965 from Cape Kennedy. Since
June 28, 1965, this satellite has provided

entire day.
Prior to the address, Dr. Eisenhower
will confer upon Mr. McCormack the
honorary degree, Doctor of Laws. Mr.
McCormack will be presented for the
degree by Dr. Harry Woolf, Willis K,
Shephard Professor of the History of
Science.
In addition to his post as Comsat's
chairman of the board, Mr. McCormack
serves as chairman and chief executive
officer of that corporation. The Comsat board is composed of 12 directors
elected by the public shareholders and
communications common carriers and
3 members appointed by the President
of the United States, with the advice
and consent of the Senate.
The Communications Satellite Corporation is an outgrowth of the Communications Satellite Act of 1962. A
private corporation established to set

James McCormack
a communications link between North
America and Europe.
A retired U.S. Air Force Maj. General,
Mr. McCormack held the MIT vice
presidency from 1957 until his Comsat
appointment on December 1, 1965. He
participated in the formulation of MIT
policy and supervised the Institute's
two largest research programs, Lincoln

Laboratory and the Instrumentation
Laboratory. He has participated in several major studies, including the
Rockefeller Study on Prospect for
America: the Gaither Panel on the
National Security, and the Draper Committee on Foreign Military Assistance.
From 1956 to 1958, the Hopkins Commemoration Day speaker served as the
first president of the Institute for Defense Analysis, a consortium of ten
universities supporting the Defense Department and other federal agencies in
science and technology. He helped organize Educational Services, Inc.,
which played an important role in the
revision of school curricula.
Mr. McCormack is a graduate of the
U.S. Military Academy and was a
Rhodes Scholar at Oxford University.
This Year's Commemoration Day is
the 90th gathering of the Hopkins faculty, students, alumni, and community since the first Such occasion on the
same date in 1876. In ceremonies that
year, Daniel Coit Gilman was inaugurated president in a crowded Academy of Music auditorium on Howard
near Centre Streets. Present on that
first Commemoration Day was President Charles W. Eliot of Harvard who
delivered the congratulatory address to
those responsible for the founding of
America's first "model university."

By JOHN M. BR1CKMAN

An 8-2-1 vote of the Interfraternity
Council Judicial Board last Monday
night denied Phi Kappa Psi the privilege
of rushing and pledging members for
the remainder of this semester.
The action reverses a motion passed
by the IFC before semester break, which
would have permitted Phi Psi to rush
and pledge. New evidence, in the form
of a letter written by two Goucher freshmen and addressed to IFC Representative Ogden Hamilton, was responsible
for the Council's determination that Phi
Psi had violated its probation terms and
for the subsequent rush ban.
The Judicial Board determined that
Phi Psi violated its probation by (a),
having a party on September 30th—the
first day of the fall semester—with
more than five couples in attendance.
and (b), by permiting two Hopkins
freshmen to enter the fraternity house
for the purpose of borrowing an identification card.
Question Raised
The question of possible violation of
the probation was first, raised by the
letter of January 23rd, and was brought
before the full IFC at last Friday's meeting. At that time, the Council decided
to hold the Judicial Board proceeding on
Monday.
Subsequent to the IFC's decision to
hold a judicial proceeding, one of the
girls who had signed the letter retracted
her signature. The other reported pressure—by Phi Psi members, other
Goucher students and Hopkins freshmen—to withdraw her signature as well.
Not Rush Violation
Alan Parter, IFC vice president and
chairman of the Judicial Board, stressed
that Phi Psi was not tried for a violation
of the rush regulations. This was impossible, he said, because the alleged
violations were reported more than 48
hours after they had occured. Rather,
the fraternity was tried for violation of
the probation terms imposed after last
year's Fort McHenry incident.
Before the final vote was taken, Dave
Kagan, president of Phi Psi, commented
that unfavorable action by the IFC was
likely to endanger the fraternity's chances of obtaining a new house, and added that a representative of the Phi
Kappa Psi national organization had
Intimated were the rush ban to take
effect) that it might be best for the
chapter to disaffiliate and become a
local fraternity.
Alumni Response
On Tuesday, Larry Schmidt, IFC president, was called in by Robert MacGill,
the University's assistant director of
alumni relations, and told that, from
the alumni standpoint, the Council's action was unwise in that it threatened
to compromise Phi Psi's opportunity to
acquire new quarters. From other houses
in the same economic position, added
MacGill, the imposition of the penalty
was an unfair thing to do. Schmidt told
MacGill that "Phi Kappa Psi's members
should have thought about this first."

The Student Council passed an
amendment to the Honor Commission constitution at its meeting in Levering Hall February 14.
The amendment pertained to
Article 8, Section 5 of the constitution and changed the penalty
code.

Under the old system, five votes
were necessary to impose the constitutional penalty on the first
conviction, but only one vote is
necessary in the ease of a second
conviction. In the amendment
proposed by Bruce Fisher representing the Honor Commission,
the penalties remain the same.
However, the constitutional penalty can be waived by a vote of
four members of the trial panel
and a new penalty can be imposed by a vote of five members.
This gives the panel greater flexibility in dealing with special
cases, such as seniors who would
be forced to return another year
if failure were applied, and Provides a mechanism for the panel
to decide on alternate penalties.
The amendment was approved by
a vote of 12-2-0.
Election Schedule
Dennis Clements of the elections committee
proposed a
change in the schedule of elections this year. The present calendar calls for presidential elections April 18, but the by-laws
require elections by the end of
March. It was decided to make
petitions available to presidential
candidates March 7 and to hold
elections at the end of the
month.

forum

the

that it was an excellent idea, but
one which the council should
have thought of and not just
the sophomore class.
The council also approved a
resolution by Michaelson to
form a committee to investigate
the possibility of a reading period before exams.

Making Book
That something is wrong with the present Bookstore, few dispute. And the problem is increasing, because, as senior class president Peter Finley puts it, of
"the increasing size of the llniversity, the specialization
in courses, and the flood of new literary materials on
the market."
Unfortunately, there is no one way out of the dilemma. Certainly, next year's move and resultant increase in floor space will remove present inherent limitations on depth and breadth of stock, and will permit the
Bookstore to carry such currently-unavailable items as
phonograph records. But the move is not a cure-all.
Why should one pay list price for recordings (as $ueh
merchandise will undoubtedly cost, in keeping with the
Bookstore's present policy on books and supplies), when
a short trip off campus allows one to buy records at a
substantial discount? More is needed.
Professor Hunt's proposals, as outlined in a report
to the Long Range Planning Commission, provide at
least a start in thjs directinon. Now, the problem is one
of implementation. First, it is unfortunate that the Bookstore situation is considered as a "long range" problem;
questions raised seem far too immediate. Next, if the
simple response of an increase in floor space—and the
Bookstore's upcoming move cannot be seen as anything
more than that—comes four years after the initial letter signed by an many department heads and faculty
members, how long must we wait for institutional reforms?
A speedy solution, it would seem, will come only
from without the administration. Consider the skuation
at other campuses: At the University of Maryland, the
University bookstore competes with a private firm, the
Maryland Book Exchange, which is located adjacent to
the school's grounds. While the latter store does not
necessarily discount items, it does have a large stock
of both required and other hooks, as well as supplies.
Thus, the University bookstore does not enjoy a virtual
monopoly, as does ours. At Columbia, the campus bookmore does discount some items, and the entire Morningside Heights neighborhood is packed with a wide
variety of booksellers. Likewise, Harvard Square is filled
with bookstores. And Harvard, as well as Yale, has a
cooperative, open to the general public as well as University people. All pay cash; students and faculty register
each purchase and receive a rebate—sometimes as high
as ten percent—at the end of the year.
It is unrealistic to compare university patronage at
these other stores with that which might lw expected
if an independent bookstore were to open in the Homewood vicinity. Hopkins is simply not large enough to
support, by itself, a commercial bookstore. But Hopkins
business could well be the nucleus for a store in the
area, and the added, even if slight, inconvenience, of
having to go off campus to purchase books and supplies
might well be offset if such a store were to offer students
a much wider selection of merchandise, and, most important, a discount—whether on the spot or under a
cooperative arrangement. Baltimore has few decent
bookstores as it is, and the city is large enough to support another—especially one of high quality.

ffis The Season . • •
Rush is again upon us, and the occasion will undoubtedly be marked by the seasonal phenomena of
jewelry glittering on the chests of fraternity brothers,
the urgent imprecations by rush chairman "not to blow
your cool", movies for a few, and a generally heroic eon.
sumption of beer.
We offer no advice to freshmen, for our voice would
only be one of many, lost in a sea of impassioned pleas,
rock' and roll music, and foam. We will, though, be interested in noting whether this year's total of freshmen
pledging matches last year's record—if so there would
seem to he a distinct comment on the administration's
1962 decision to segregate freshmen in their own dormitories, and to defer rusing until second semester.
Re the Phi Kappa Psi situation: we note with displeasure the incident in which the University's assistant
director of alumni relations expressed "alumni disapproval" of the WC action to President Schmidt. Conversely, we are pleased that Dean Morrill_ chose to back
the WC Judicial Board in any action it may have taken.
The Dean was right—this was a decision to be made by
the fraternity's peers, without administration interference. And whether or not one disagrees with the IFC
derision, one must agree that the administration acted
properly in backing that decision.

REPUBLICAN BIAS

More Federal Aid, Less Intervention

--]

By WYATT B. DITRRETTE, JR. .
When one considers what the
'role of the national government
Is to be in financing elementary
and secondary education, he
should—unless he be cursed with
that blind faith which holds
that everything can be best done
from
Washington—ask
some
questions. 1) Is there really a
problem serious enough to require national action? 2) If so,
what are its causes? 3) What
type of action is appropriate? 4)
Assuming that there is a problem whose cause can be remedied
by some national action, and assume further that we desire to
preserve local control and diversity in education (which
some misguided souls, quite certain of their own particular wisdom, will not grant); assuming
this, how can we have national
relief without the control?
The usual rallying cry from
the "let Washington do everything" crowd Ls that the state
and local governments have
failed to meet the challenge and
action is demanded immediately.
But consider the following
facts. In the 10 school years
prior to the enactment of the
Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965, pupil-enrollment in the nation's elementary public schools rose 30 million to 42.9 million, or 43'4. Revenues for education leaped from
$8.5 billion to $21.8 billion, or
15%. All but 4% of these monies
eame from state and local
sources: national participation
was miniscule..
Of course, money is only one
measurement, but note also that
the number of classrooms increased 58,V,, instructional staffs
grew 56%, teachers' salaries rose
65% (the national average for
other wage earners improved by
only 44%), the number of pu-

pils per teacher dropped from
26 to 23.9, and finally 70,000
classroonris a year have been
built locally (700,000 from 19541964), whereas the late President Kennedy pleaded for only
60,000 per year. In this decade
of monumental progress, elementary and secondary school
enrollment increased, as noted,
43%, while projections for the
next decade forecast only 13%.
From these facts most Republican legislators have concluded
that the case for national involvement in elementary and
secondary education embodied
in the Act of 1965 is weak indeed. The minority report makes
this clear and concludes that
the motives of its supporters
were not altogether "educational." For example, the bulk of
the funds—$1 billion in the first
year—are to be distributed under Title I of the Act which purports to follow the outline of the
federal government. The result
of the "formula," however, is
that the funds would be dis-

persed widely among 94% of
the nation's counties.
The 10 wealthiest counties
will receive $8.'918,087 for 32.563
eligible children, while 10 poor
counties are allotted $4.507,149
for 32,452 eligible children. The
median incomes in the first
group range from $7,371 to
$9,317 and in the second from
$1,260 to $2,437. The wealthiest
county in the U.S. even receives
/
1
2 million rollars to fight "poverty" in its schools. The political
reasons for giving nearly every
county a vested interest are obvious, and the Republicans tried
to strengthen the bill by amend=
ment to eliminate the wealthiest
counties from the benefit of
Federal funds, thus concentrating assistance in urban slum
and poor rural districts and to
focus every title of the bill on
programs for educationally and
economically deprived children.
That the reality of Federal
control is no myth can be demonstrated by two examples. Illinois Congressman Robert H.

Michel recently made public a
"confidential" memorandum of
a Federal Office of Education
executive group meeting of August 26, 1965 which laid down
the following "guideline"; "No
Office of Education hand is to
be tied by 1) having to deal
only through a backward state
education agency or 2) not being able to deal directly with urban jurisdiction, however, competent the state education agency, when direct relationships
seem most In the public interest."
The Republican alternatives
seek to accomplish two goals
which are so obviously desirable
that no positive argumentation
seems necessary: 1) assist directly school districts having a
high concentration of deprived
families, and 21 avoid Federal
control by returning revenue resources to the states, localities,
and institutions by means of tax
credits and direct payments to
needy recipients. One such proposal by Congressman Richard

H. Poll' of Virginia was to authorize a credit (not deduction)
against the Federal Income Tax
for new prospective state and
local taxes imposed for school
improvement purposes.
The Republican suggestions
have had great appeal to those
who value educational diversity,
to those who are not enraptured
by the myths of the 1930's that
all wisdom and enlightenment
originates on the Potomac and
to those who genuinely want to
protnote progress in education
and not progress in politics.
Because the national government's role would be seriously
modified under the GOP proposals, the Administration and
the election-minded Congress it
controls rejected them last year
and are likely to do so again.
Though it may benefit the
Democratic party (not necessarily, however, if the Republican
message can be heard), the Administration's present education policies hardly benefit the
American public.

On the waterfront
at Annapolisgrowth opportunities for
research engineers
and scientists
The U. S. Navy Marine Engineering Laboratory conducts RDT&E in naval shipboard and submarine machinery and
auxiliary systems (electrical, propulsion,
control, etc.). In addition to developing
basic improvements in performance and
reliability, the Laboratory concentrates on
ship silencing, new concepts in energy
conversion and control, ways to minimize
friction and wear, special operating machinery for deep-diving vessels; and tough,
resistant naval alloys to meet all ocean
environmental conditions.
The Laboratory buildings—now more
than 50 of them—house some of the finest
research, experimental and evaluation
equipments of their kind, such as highspeed computers, electric power generators,
vibration and shock test stands, metals
composition analysis instruments, cryogenic storage and handling facilities, physics and chemistry labs, and complex instrumentation for measuring strain, stress,
pressure, acceleration, velocity, performance, and reliability. The Laboratory
grounds resemble a modern industrial
park, and include special facilities for
in-field experimentation.
And the locale is ideal. Washington,
Baltimore and the ocean resorts are no
more than one hour's drive. Annapolis itself is the state capital, and offers smallcity living with metropolitan accessibility.
Urgent new projects require additional
engineering and scientific personnel with
BS, MS, and PhD degrees.

Typical Duties of Engineers and
Scientists at MEL:
Mechanical Engineers—Research and development in shipboard propulsion machinery—pneumatic and hydraulic systems
—friction and wear equipment and devices
—machinery silencing—and many other
naval and shipboard mechanical applications.
Electrical Engineers—Research and development in electrical power and its control—magnetic fields—ship control systems
—instrumentation—electro-chemical proc-.
esses—electro/electromechanical equipment silencing—plus a variety of additional
naval anii'toipboard electrical applications..

Electronic Engineers—Research and development in electronics—servo-mechanisms
—electromechanical devices—instrument
and panel illumination—pressure measurement—fluid flow measurement.
Chemical Engineers—Research and development work in chemical and electrochemical processes; gas and fluid flow
systems and equipment; air and water
treatment systems; semi-conductor materials; lubrication; fuel systems and processes; filtration; hydraulic fuel systems.

Physicists—Application of physical principles to the areas of sound, electronics,
optics, mechanics, instrumentation, or
electricity and magnetism.
Chemists—Engaged in application of chemical winciples to the areas of water treatmei . and purification, corrosion and deposit,on in naval equipment, atmosphere
purification, thermoelectric materials, fuel
cell power generation, lubrication, fuels,
hydraulic fluids, and instrumental analysis.
Metallurgists—Research and development
work in the area of new or improved alloys
for ship hull and machinery applications
involving considerations of physical and
mechanical properties of metals and alloys, fatigue and corrosion characteristics,
and weldability.
Salaries range from $6,027 to $10,619 per
year, depending on type of degree and
scholastic standing.
Appointees acquire the benefits of career
Civil Service and regular salary increases.
All applicants will be considered on the
basis of merit without regard to sex, race,
creed, color, national origin, age, physical
handicap, marital status, or lawful political affiliation.
If you are interested in applying your
capabilities to the vital and expanding
business of improving ship and submarine
performances, arrange with your College
Placement Officer to see the Laboratory's
recruiting representative, who will be on
campus for interviews on

MONDAY, FEB. 28
or, write to:
W. M. SIESKO
Head, Employment Branch
U. S. Navy Marine Engineering Laboratory
Annapolis, Maryland

JHU Bookstore
Supports School
By JIM WULACH
The university earns about $25,000
from bookstore profits every year, according to a report recently written by
Dr. Charles Hunt, of the Hopkins
Geography Department. Whereas many
college bookstores are non-profit organizations with education as their primary
purpose, the dominant philosophy of
the University Bookstore is that it is
"first and last a business enterprise."
A survey conducted five years ago and
signed by 85 faculty members, including
19 departmen chairmen, recommended
that improvements be made. The survey
indicated that "the Hopkins bookstore
Is one of the poorer ones among major
Universities, for it has not been allowed
the staff, space, and facilities to develop
otherwise." However, present plans for
change, which include more bookstore
space, and a rearrangement of books
according to subject, are "only palliative
and quite inadequate," Dr. Hunt stated.
(Continued on Page 3)

Tuesday evening marked the commencement of the annual rush period at
Hopkins, as fraternity men converged
on the freshman dormitories en masse.
Both fraternities and freshmen are expected to exercise great selectivity, the
freshmen looking for the most congenial
fraternity and each fraternity seeking a
qualitatively and quantitatively superior
pledge class.
Tonight begins the two-week round of
open-house parties, with the freshmen
being welcomed at those fraternities
south of the campus from 8 p.m. until
1 a.m. These houses are Alpha Delta Phi,
Alpha Tau Omega, Alpha Epsilon Pi,
Sigma Phi Epsilon, Phi Epsilon Pi, Zeta
Beta Tau, and Kappa Alpha. Saturday
evening the freshmen are all invited to
visit Delta Phi, Delta Upsilon, Phi Gamma Delta, Tau Epsilon Phi, Phi Sigma
Delta, and Beta Theta Pi.
Next week will follow the same schedule of rush Tuesday evening from seven
to ten p.m. and Wednesday and Thursday afternoon rush from noon to five
p.m. However,, those fraternities which
hold parties tonight will have their second parties on Saturday of next week,
and those fraternities which will have
their parties tomorrow evening will
have their second parties next Friday.
For the third and final week of rush,
all fraternities will have invitational
parties on Friday evening, March 4, followed by their private pledge parties
on Pledge Saturday, March 5, after the
freshmen have submitted their bids
( with a five-dollar fee) to the IFC that
morning.

February 22. 3 p.m. in Shriver
President Eisenhower will preside at

By JOHN M. BR1CKMAN

An 8-2-1 vote of the Interfraternity
Council Judicial Board last Monday
night denied Phi Kappa Psi the privilege
of rushing and pledging members for
the remainder of this semester.
The action reverses a motion passed
by the IFC before semester break, which
would have permitted Phi Psi to rush
and pledge. New evidence, in the form
of a letter written by two Goucher freshmen and addressed to IFC Representative Ogden Hamilton, was responsible
for the Council's determination that Phi
Psi had violated its probation terms and
for the subsequent rush ban.
The Judicial Board determined that
Phi Psi violated its probation by (a),
having a party on September 30th—the
first day of the fall semester—with
more than five couples in attendance.
and (b), by permiting two Hopkins
freshmen to enter the fraternity house
for the purpose of borrowing an identification card.
Question Raised
The question of possible violation of
the probation was first, raised by the
letter of January 23rd, and was brought
before the full IFC at last Friday's meeting. At that time, the Council decided
to hold the Judicial Board proceeding on
Monday.
Subsequent to the IFC's decision to
hold a judicial proceeding, one of the
girls who had signed the letter retracted
her signature. The other reported pressure—by Phi Psi members, other
Goucher students and Hopkins freshmen—to withdraw her signature as well.
Not Rush Violation
Alan Parter, IFC vice president and
chairman of the Judicial Board, stressed
that Phi Psi was not tried for a violation
of the rush regulations. This was impossible, he said, because the alleged
violations were reported more than 48
hours after they had occured. Rather,
the fraternity was tried for violation of
the probation terms imposed after last
year's Fort McHenry incident.
Before the final vote was taken, Dave
Kagan, president of Phi Psi, commented
that unfavorable action by the IFC was
likely to endanger the fraternity's chances of obtaining a new house, and added that a representative of the Phi
Kappa Psi national organization had
Intimated were the rush ban to take
effect) that it might be best for the
chapter to disaffiliate and become a
local fraternity.
Alumni Response
On Tuesday, Larry Schmidt, IFC president, was called in by Robert MacGill,
the University's assistant director of
alumni relations, and told that, from
the alumni standpoint, the Council's action was unwise in that it threatened
to compromise Phi Psi's opportunity to
acquire new quarters. From other houses
in the same economic position, added
MacGill, the imposition of the penalty
was an unfair thing to do. Schmidt told
MacGill that "Phi Kappa Psi's members
should have thought about this first."

Under the old system, five votes
were necessary to impose the constitutional penalty on the first
conviction, but only one vote is
necessary in the ease of a second
conviction. In the amendment
proposed by Bruce Fisher representing the Honor Commission,
the penalties remain the same.
However, the constitutional penalty can be waived by a vote of
four members of the trial panel
and a new penalty can be imposed by a vote of five members.
This gives the panel greater flexibility in dealing with special
cases, such as seniors who would
be forced to return another year
if failure were applied, and Provides a mechanism for the panel
to decide on alternate penalties.

Making Book
That something is wrong with the present Bookstore, few dispute. And the problem is increasing, because, as senior class president Peter Finley puts it, of
"the increasing size of the llniversity, the specialization
in courses, and the flood of new literary materials on
the market."
Unfortunately, there is no one way out of the dilemma. Certainly, next year's move and resultant increase in floor space will remove present inherent limitations on depth and breadth of stock, and will permit the
Bookstore to carry such currently-unavailable items as
phonograph records. But the move is not a cure-all.
Why should one pay list price for recordings (as $ueh
merchandise will undoubtedly cost, in keeping with the
Bookstore's present policy on books and supplies), when
a short trip off campus allows one to buy records at a
substantial discount? More is needed.
Professor Hunt's proposals, as outlined in a report
to the Long Range Planning Commission, provide at
least a start in thjs directinon. Now, the problem is one
of implementation. First, it is unfortunate that the Bookstore situation is considered as a "long range" problem;
questions raised seem far too immediate. Next, if the
simple response of an increase in floor space—and the
Bookstore's upcoming move cannot be seen as anything
more than that—comes four years after the initial letter signed by an many department heads and faculty
members, how long must we wait for institutional reforms?
A speedy solution, it would seem, will come only
from without the administration. Consider the skuation
at other campuses: At the University of Maryland, the
University bookstore competes with a private firm, the
Maryland Book Exchange, which is located adjacent to
the school's grounds. While the latter store does not
necessarily discount items, it does have a large stock
of both required and other hooks, as well as supplies.
Thus, the University bookstore does not enjoy a virtual
monopoly, as does ours. At Columbia, the campus bookmore does discount some items, and the entire Morningside Heights neighborhood is packed with a wide
variety of booksellers. Likewise, Harvard Square is filled
with bookstores. And Harvard, as well as Yale, has a
cooperative, open to the general public as well as University people. All pay cash; students and faculty register
each purchase and receive a rebate—sometimes as high
as ten percent—at the end of the year.
It is unrealistic to compare university patronage at
these other stores with that which might lw expected
if an independent bookstore were to open in the Homewood vicinity. Hopkins is simply not large enough to
support, by itself, a commercial bookstore. But Hopkins
business could well be the nucleus for a store in the
area, and the added, even if slight, inconvenience, of
having to go off campus to purchase books and supplies
might well be offset if such a store were to offer students
a much wider selection of merchandise, and, most important, a discount—whether on the spot or under a
cooperative arrangement. Baltimore has few decent
bookstores as it is, and the city is large enough to support another—especially one of high quality.

ffis The Season . • •
Rush is again upon us, and the occasion will undoubtedly be marked by the seasonal phenomena of
jewelry glittering on the chests of fraternity brothers,
the urgent imprecations by rush chairman "not to blow
your cool", movies for a few, and a generally heroic eon.
sumption of beer.
We offer no advice to freshmen, for our voice would
only be one of many, lost in a sea of impassioned pleas,
rock' and roll music, and foam. We will, though, be interested in noting whether this year's total of freshmen
pledging matches last year's record—if so there would
seem to he a distinct comment on the administration's
1962 decision to segregate freshmen in their own dormitories, and to defer rusing until second semester.
Re the Phi Kappa Psi situation: we note with displeasure the incident in which the University's assistant
director of alumni relations expressed "alumni disapproval" of the WC action to President Schmidt. Conversely, we are pleased that Dean Morrill_ chose to back
the WC Judicial Board in any action it may have taken.
The Dean was right—this was a decision to be made by
the fraternity's peers, without administration interference. And whether or not one disagrees with the IFC
derision, one must agree that the administration acted
properly in backing that decision.

REPUBLICAN BIAS

More Federal Aid, Less Intervention

--]

By WYATT B. DITRRETTE, JR. .
When one considers what the
'role of the national government
Is to be in financing elementary
and secondary education, he
should—unless he be cursed with
that blind faith which holds
that everything can be best done
from
Washington—ask
some
questions. 1) Is there really a
problem serious enough to require national action? 2) If so,
what are its causes? 3) What
type of action is appropriate? 4)
Assuming that there is a problem whose cause can be remedied
by some national action, and assume further that we desire to
preserve local control and diversity in education (which
some misguided souls, quite certain of their own particular wisdom, will not grant); assuming
this, how can we have national
relief without the control?
The usual rallying cry from
the "let Washington do everything" crowd Ls that the state
and local governments have
failed to meet the challenge and
action is demanded immediately.
But consider the following
facts. In the 10 school years
prior to the enactment of the
Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965, pupil-enrollment in the nation's elementary public schools rose 30 million to 42.9 million, or 43'4. Revenues for education leaped from
$8.5 billion to $21.8 billion, or
15%. All but 4% of these monies
eame from state and local
sources: national participation
was miniscule..
Of course, money is only one
measurement, but note also that
the number of classrooms increased 58,V,, instructional staffs
grew 56%, teachers' salaries rose
65% (the national average for
other wage earners improved by
only 44%), the number of pu-

pils per teacher dropped from
26 to 23.9, and finally 70,000
classroonris a year have been
built locally (700,000 from 19541964), whereas the late President Kennedy pleaded for only
60,000 per year. In this decade
of monumental progress, elementary and secondary school
enrollment increased, as noted,
43%, while projections for the
next decade forecast only 13%.
From these facts most Republican legislators have concluded
that the case for national involvement in elementary and
secondary education embodied
in the Act of 1965 is weak indeed. The minority report makes
this clear and concludes that
the motives of its supporters
were not altogether "educational." For example, the bulk of
the funds—$1 billion in the first
year—are to be distributed under Title I of the Act which purports to follow the outline of the
federal government. The result
of the "formula," however, is
that the funds would be dis-

persed widely among 94% of
the nation's counties.
The 10 wealthiest counties
will receive $8.'918,087 for 32.563
eligible children, while 10 poor
counties are allotted $4.507,149
for 32,452 eligible children. The
median incomes in the first
group range from $7,371 to
$9,317 and in the second from
$1,260 to $2,437. The wealthiest
county in the U.S. even receives
/
1
2 million rollars to fight "poverty" in its schools. The political
reasons for giving nearly every
county a vested interest are obvious, and the Republicans tried
to strengthen the bill by amend=
ment to eliminate the wealthiest
counties from the benefit of
Federal funds, thus concentrating assistance in urban slum
and poor rural districts and to
focus every title of the bill on
programs for educationally and
economically deprived children.
That the reality of Federal
control is no myth can be demonstrated by two examples. Illinois Congressman Robert H.

Michel recently made public a
"confidential" memorandum of
a Federal Office of Education
executive group meeting of August 26, 1965 which laid down
the following "guideline"; "No
Office of Education hand is to
be tied by 1) having to deal
only through a backward state
education agency or 2) not being able to deal directly with urban jurisdiction, however, competent the state education agency, when direct relationships
seem most In the public interest."
The Republican alternatives
seek to accomplish two goals
which are so obviously desirable
that no positive argumentation
seems necessary: 1) assist directly school districts having a
high concentration of deprived
families, and 21 avoid Federal
control by returning revenue resources to the states, localities,
and institutions by means of tax
credits and direct payments to
needy recipients. One such proposal by Congressman Richard

H. Poll' of Virginia was to authorize a credit (not deduction)
against the Federal Income Tax
for new prospective state and
local taxes imposed for school
improvement purposes.
The Republican suggestions
have had great appeal to those
who value educational diversity,
to those who are not enraptured
by the myths of the 1930's that
all wisdom and enlightenment
originates on the Potomac and
to those who genuinely want to
protnote progress in education
and not progress in politics.
Because the national government's role would be seriously
modified under the GOP proposals, the Administration and
the election-minded Congress it
controls rejected them last year
and are likely to do so again.
Though it may benefit the
Democratic party (not necessarily, however, if the Republican
message can be heard), the Administration's present education policies hardly benefit the
American public.

On the waterfront
at Annapolisgrowth opportunities for
research engineers
and scientists
The U. S. Navy Marine Engineering Laboratory conducts RDT&E in naval shipboard and submarine machinery and
auxiliary systems (electrical, propulsion,
control, etc.). In addition to developing
basic improvements in performance and
reliability, the Laboratory concentrates on
ship silencing, new concepts in energy
conversion and control, ways to minimize
friction and wear, special operating machinery for deep-diving vessels; and tough,
resistant naval alloys to meet all ocean
environmental conditions.
The Laboratory buildings—now more
than 50 of them—house some of the finest
research, experimental and evaluation
equipments of their kind, such as highspeed computers, electric power generators,
vibration and shock test stands, metals
composition analysis instruments, cryogenic storage and handling facilities, physics and chemistry labs, and complex instrumentation for measuring strain, stress,
pressure, acceleration, velocity, performance, and reliability. The Laboratory
grounds resemble a modern industrial
park, and include special facilities for
in-field experimentation.
And the locale is ideal. Washington,
Baltimore and the ocean resorts are no
more than one hour's drive. Annapolis itself is the state capital, and offers smallcity living with metropolitan accessibility.
Urgent new projects require additional
engineering and scientific personnel with
BS, MS, and PhD degrees.

Typical Duties of Engineers and
Scientists at MEL:
Mechanical Engineers—Research and development in shipboard propulsion machinery—pneumatic and hydraulic systems
—friction and wear equipment and devices
—machinery silencing—and many other
naval and shipboard mechanical applications.
Electrical Engineers—Research and development in electrical power and its control—magnetic fields—ship control systems
—instrumentation—electro-chemical proc-.
esses—electro/electromechanical equipment silencing—plus a variety of additional
naval anii'toipboard electrical applications..

Electronic Engineers—Research and development in electronics—servo-mechanisms
—electromechanical devices—instrument
and panel illumination—pressure measurement—fluid flow measurement.
Chemical Engineers—Research and development work in chemical and electrochemical processes; gas and fluid flow
systems and equipment; air and water
treatment systems; semi-conductor materials; lubrication; fuel systems and processes; filtration; hydraulic fuel systems.

Physicists—Application of physical principles to the areas of sound, electronics,
optics, mechanics, instrumentation, or
electricity and magnetism.
Chemists—Engaged in application of chemical winciples to the areas of water treatmei . and purification, corrosion and deposit,on in naval equipment, atmosphere
purification, thermoelectric materials, fuel
cell power generation, lubrication, fuels,
hydraulic fluids, and instrumental analysis.
Metallurgists—Research and development
work in the area of new or improved alloys
for ship hull and machinery applications
involving considerations of physical and
mechanical properties of metals and alloys, fatigue and corrosion characteristics,
and weldability.
Salaries range from $6,027 to $10,619 per
year, depending on type of degree and
scholastic standing.
Appointees acquire the benefits of career
Civil Service and regular salary increases.
All applicants will be considered on the
basis of merit without regard to sex, race,
creed, color, national origin, age, physical
handicap, marital status, or lawful political affiliation.
If you are interested in applying your
capabilities to the vital and expanding
business of improving ship and submarine
performances, arrange with your College
Placement Officer to see the Laboratory's
recruiting representative, who will be on
campus for interviews on

MONDAY, FEB. 28
or, write to:
W. M. SIESKO
Head, Employment Branch
U. S. Navy Marine Engineering Laboratory
Annapolis, Maryland
